caption:
Table 1: 
Comparison of different attention mechanisms. Here, RQsubscript𝑅𝑄R_{Q}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, RKsubscript𝑅𝐾R_{K}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and RVsubscript𝑅𝑉R_{V}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the ranks for queries, keys, and values in TPA, respectively. Variants of TPA, such as TPA (KVonly), TPA (Non-contextual A), and TPA (Non-contextual B), are detailed in Section 3.5. For MLA, dhRsuperscriptsubscript𝑑ℎ𝑅d_{h}^{R}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and dhsubscript𝑑ℎd_{h}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the dimensions for RoPE and non-RoPE parts; dc′superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑐′d_{c}^{\prime}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and dcsubscript𝑑𝑐d_{c}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the dimensions of compressed vectors for query and key-value, respectively.
description: Table 1 compares different attention mechanisms in terms of their parameter count, KV cache size, number of query heads, and number of key-value heads.  It shows how the Tensor Product Attention (TPA) and its variants compare to Multi-Head Attention (MHA), Multi-Query Attention (MQA), Grouped-Query Attention (GQA), and Multi-head Latent Attention (MLA). The table details the ranks of the tensor factorization in TPA for queries, keys, and values and specifies the dimensions of the compressed vectors used in MLA. It provides a quantitative comparison to understand the differences in computational cost and memory efficiency of various attention mechanisms.

description: This table presents the zero-shot performance of medium-sized language models (353M parameters) on several downstream tasks. description: This table presents the results of evaluating medium-sized language models (353M parameters) on various downstream tasks.  These models were pre-trained using the FineWeb-Edu 100B dataset and utilize different attention mechanisms. The evaluation is conducted using a 2-shot prompting approach with the 'lm-evaluation-harness' tool.  The table shows the performance (accuracy or accuracy norm) of each model on several benchmark datasets, including ARC-E, ARC-C, BoolQ, HellaSwag, OBQA, PIQA, Winogrande, and MMLU.  The best-performing model for each task is highlighted in bold.

description: This table presents the zero-shot performance of large language models (773M parameters) on various downstream tasks.  The models used different attention mechanisms: Multi-Head Attention (MHA), Multi-Query Attention (MQA), Grouped-Query Attention (GQA), Multi-head Latent Attention (MLA), and the proposed Tensor Product Attention (TPA) and its variant TPA-KVonly.  The FineWeb-Edu 100B dataset was used for pre-training. The table shows the accuracy scores achieved by each model on several benchmark datasets, including ARC-E, ARC-C, BoolQ, HellaSwag, OBQA, PIQA, Winogrande, MMLU, and SciQ.  The best-performing model for each task is highlighted in bold.

description: This table presents the downstream evaluation results for large language models (773M parameters) pre-trained on the FineWeb-Edu 100B dataset.  The models utilize different attention mechanisms, including Multi-Head Attention (MHA), Multi-Query Attention (MQA), Grouped Query Attention (GQA), Multi-head Latent Attention (MLA), and the proposed Tensor Product Attention (TPA) and its variant TPA-KVonly.  The evaluation is performed using a 2-shot prompting method with the lm-evaluation-harness, covering several benchmark datasets: ARC-E, ARC-C, BoolQ, HellaSwag, OBQA, PIQA, WinoGrande, MMLU, and SciQ. The best performance for each dataset is highlighted in bold.  The abbreviations 'HellaSw.' and 'W.G.' are used for HellaSwag and WinoGrande respectively.

caption: Table 6: The architecture hyper-parameters and training devices of models. Abbreviations: BS. = Batch Size, GAS. = Gradient Accumulation Steps.
description: This table details the experimental setup used for training different sized language models. It shows the model size (in terms of parameters), the number of parameters, the hardware used (number of GPUs and their type), the batch size, the gradient accumulation steps, the number of layers in the model, and the embedding dimension (d_model).  The abbreviations BS. and GAS. stand for Batch Size and Gradient Accumulation Steps, respectively.

description: This table presents the architectural hyperparameters used for training the different sized language models in the paper.  It shows how the number of heads, hidden dimensions, and other key parameters varied across small, medium, and large model configurations. This information is crucial to understanding the differences in model complexity and performance across the various model sizes evaluated in the experiments.  The specific attention mechanisms (MHA, MQA, GQA, MLA, TPA-KVonly, and TPA) and their hyperparameters are also listed.

Each model employs a different attention mechanism (MHA, MQA, GQA, MLA, TPA, TPA-KVonly) while being pre-trained on the FineWeb-Edu 100B dataset.  The results, expressed as accuracy or accuracy norm, showcase the comparative performance of these attention mechanisms, highlighting which attention method yields the best results for each downstream task.  Abbreviations such as HellaSw. for HellaSwag and W.G. for Winogrande are used for brevity.

description: This table presents the results of evaluating medium-sized language models (with a learning rate of 6 x 10^-4) that use different attention mechanisms.  The models were pre-trained on the FineWeb-Edu 100B dataset. The evaluation used a 2-shot prompt approach and the lm-evaluation-harness toolkit.  The table shows the performance across several benchmark datasets (ARC-E, ARC-C, BoolQ, HellaSwag, OBQA, PIQA, Winogrande, MMLU, and SciQ).  The best scores for each benchmark are highlighted in bold.
